attributes.title: Sensory processing sensitivity, health and well-being

q1.value: Sensory processing sensitivity and its relation to stress, depression, somatic symptoms, worry, mindfulness and self-referential processing.

q3.value:
Previous research has found that individuals with higher levels of sensory processing sensitivity (SPS) experience higher levels of depression, somatic symptoms, and stress. Similarly, in my undergraduate dissertation I found that SPS positively correlated with perceived stress and somatic symptoms and they were partially mediated by worry. The undergraduate dissertation by Sorensen (2019) did not find a significant relationship between SPS and depression despite previous research finding significant positive correlations which may have been due using a different depression scale (the PHQ-8). Sorensen (2019) also measured mindfulness (acceptance and awareness) but there was a technical error. Therefore, the aim of the current study is to replicate the findings from Sorensen (2019) using the same validated scales but a different depression scale (the MDI instead of PHQ-8) and have the full data for the mindfulness (awareness and acceptance) variable. The pre-registration for Sorensen (2019) can be found on the AsPredicted website: https://aspredicted.org/pt78u.pdf 

However, the current study would like to expand on the research exploring depression in individuals with SPS. Previous research has found that negative self-referential processing is associated with depression, however, this has not been studied yet in individuals with SPS. Therefore, the current study would like to examine if individuals with SPS experience negative or positive self-referential processing, and if the self-referential processing mediates depression, perceived stress, and somatic symptoms. Furthermore, assess if worry (replication of Sorensen, 2019) and mindfulness mediate self-referential processing in SPS or if self-referential processing mediates worry and mindfulness in SPS.

q4.value:
- Replicating hypotheses: 
Primary hypothesis: 
Does mindfulness (acceptance and awareness) mediate depression, stress, and somatic symptoms in SPS? 

Secondary hypotheses: 
Does SPS correlate with depression, stress, somatic symptoms, worry, mindfulness (acceptance and awareness), neuroticism, and introversion? 
Does worry mediate depression, stress, and somatic symptoms in SPS? 
Do individuals with SPS have a higher likelihood of being diagnosed with allergies and intolerances? 

- New hypotheses: 
Primary hypotheses: 
Is self-referential processing related to SPS, stress, depression, somatic symptoms, worry and mindfulness? 
Does self-referential processing mediate depression, stress, somatic symptoms, worry and mindfulness in SPS? 

Secondary hypotheses:
Does worry mediate self-referential processing in SPS?
Does mindfulness mediate self-referential processing in SPS?
Do individuals with SPS have a higher likelihood of being diagnosed with allergies and intolerances? 
Is irritable bowel syndrome related to SPS? 
Do individuals with SPS have a higher likelihood of more severe depression?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
All participants will take an online survey using Gorilla software. The survey contains validated scales assessing perceived stress, depression, somatic symptoms, IPIP personality scales for neuroticism and extraversion, worry, mindfulness (acceptance and awareness). The software Gorilla will randomize the order of each sub-questionnaire using Latin Square. 

The participants will also complete a self-referential encoding task (SRET) in the Gorilla software. The SRET will show 40 words in total (20 positive and 20 negatives words) with one word appearing at a time and ask the participants if they think the word describes them. The words will appear in random order for each participant. One word will appear at a time together with an indication of which keyboard key is yes and no. The SRET will have a test trial with 6 self-descriptive words (3 positive and 3 negative) but none that are in the actual task. The participants will be informed when the actual task starts. Screen 1 will appear for 750 ms which say, "Describes you?". On screen number 2 one of the 40 words will appear together with two boxes, one box saying "Yes" with "Press S" below and another box saying "no" with "Press K" below. When the participants have pressed either S or K then screen 3 appears. Screen 3 has a fixation cross which will be shown for 1000 ms before moving to screen 1 with a new word appearing. Half of the participants will complete the SRET where they have to press their keyboard to answer S for yes and K for no. However, for the other half of the participants, the keyboard keys will be switched so S means no and K mean yes to counterbalance. The software Gorilla will randomly allocate each participant to one of the two conditions.

q9.value: All participants will take the sub-questionnaires in randomized order using Latin-square in the Gorilla software. The participants will also complete a self-referential encoding task (SRET) where half of the participants will answer using the keyboard key S for yes and K for no and the other half will have S for no and K for yes. The software Gorilla will randomly assign participants to each condition. The 40 self-descriptive words in the SRET will also be in randomized order for all participants which is randomized by the software.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The survey will be distributed online on social media such as Facebook.com, Reddit.com LinkedIn.com. On the social media sites, the survey will be shared to scientific groups designed to increase sample size but it will also be shared on groups related to the highly sensitive person (individuals with sensory processing sensitivity) and groups related to allergies and intolerances. Participation is on a voluntary basis and there will be no reward for completing the survey. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value:
The sample size will be a minimum of 191 based on a priori power calculations (power .80, r = .20). However, the data collection will continue until the 1st of May 2020 even if 191 participants is reached before the deadline. The data will be analysed as a whole. Participants cannot skip sub-questionnaires. 
If participants are answering the survey on a phone or iPad/tablet their results on the SRET will be removed but the data from the rest of the survey will be included in the data. Participants will be over the age of 18 years. The participants can be from anywhere in the world. The sample will be a convenience sample and using a snowball sampling technique.

q14.value: Our goal is to obtain 0.80 power to detect a medium effect of r = .20 at the standard .05 alpha error probability which is 191 participants.

q15.value: Data collecting will end on 1st of May 2020.

question.value: In the SRET the keyboard S and K are used to answer yes or no which is manipulated to change between participants. The 40 words used are chosen by the author based on frequency, arousal level and valence score from the ANEW wordlist (Bradley & Lang, 1999).

The study includes demographic questions such as age, gender, nationality and country of residence. 

Other variables are: 
- Measure of neuroticism and introversion using IPIP short-scale based on Costa and McCrae's (1992) NEO-PI-R Domains by International Personality Item Pool 
- A measure of depression using Major Depression Inventory by World Health Organization. The depression scale MDI measures a score between 0 to 50 as well as a mild, moderate or severe depression score. 
- A measure of worry using Penn State Worry Questionnaire by Meyer, Miller, Metzger and Borkovec (1990). 
- A measure of mindfulness which contains acceptance and awareness using the Philadelphia Mindfulness scales by Cardaciotto et al. (2008). 
- A measure of perceived stress using the Perceived Stress Scale by Cohen (1994). 
- A measure of sensory processing sensitivity using the Highly Sensitive Personality scale by Aron and Aron (1997) 
- A measure of somatic symptoms using the Cohen-Hoberman Inventory of Physical Symptoms by Cohen and Hoberman (1983). 
- The Self-Referent Encoding Task (SRET) by Derry and Kuiper (1981) will be used to measure self-referential processing which gives the variables: positive drift rate and negative drift rate, negative word endorsed, positive word endorsed, reaction time for negative words, reaction time for positive words. 

The study will also ask if participants have been diagnosed by a doctor with any allergies or intolerances as well as if they have been diagnosed by a doctor with irritable bowel syndrome. 
The study also asks what device the participants are answering the survey on (mobile, iPad/tablet, computer or other). 

The participants are also asked if they have completed the survey by Sorensen (2019). 

The study also has 4 attention manipulations: "Please click "3" below to show that you are reading the questions", "If you are still paying attention to the questions, click "1 very inaccurate" below", and "if you are answering to the best of your abilities click "5 very typical of me" below. Participants will also answer the age in years in the demographic section at the beginning of the survey and they will be asked to write their age again later in the survey.
If any similar constructs correlate higher than .65 then the variables will be combined to a standardized variable.

The study will run Cronbach's Alpha to check internal reliability for all variables. The 40 words used in the SRET have been picked from the Bradley and Lang (1999) Affective Norms for English Words (ANEW) list. Valence will be checked by a set of 30 participants prior to collecting data for the study and the 30 participants for the valence check will not partake in the actual study. 

T-test: 
The study will test if the positive and negative words differ in valence and test if they are different in word frequency and arousal using paired sample t-test. Before running the t-test the study will test for normal distribution using Shapiro-Wilk. The valence scores from the 30 participants will be compared to the valence from the ANEW to test if they differ using a paired sample t-test. 
A t-test will be run to assess if there is a difference between negative words endorsed and positive words endorsed. 
Another t-test will be run to examine if there is a difference between positive drift rate and negative drift rate.  

ANOVA: 
- The study will run a one way between participants ANOVA to test if there is a difference between gender and SPS score with post hoc Tukey HSD. 
- A one way between participants ANOVA to test if people who have been diagnosed by a doctor with allergies/intolerances have significantly higher somatic symptoms than participants who have not been diagnosed with any intolerances/allergies. 
- A one way between participants ANOVA to test if participants who have been diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome have more somatic symptoms. 

Correlations (two-tailed): 
The study will use Pearson's correlation coefficient to test the hypotheses that SPS correlates with stress, depression, somatic symptoms, mindfulness (acceptance and awareness), worry, self-referential processing (positive drift rate and negative drift rate, positive words endorsed, and negative words endorsed), neuroticism and introversion. 

Simple linear regression: 
- A simple linear regression will be used to test if SPS significantly predict perceived stress, somatic symptoms, depression, worry, mindfulness (awareness and acceptance). 
- A simple linear regression will be carried out to assess if worry predicts stress, somatic symptoms and depression. 
- A simple linear regression will be carried out to assess if sensory processing sensitivity predicts stress, somatic symptoms and depression. 
- A simple linear regression will be carried out to assess if mindfulness predicts stress, somatic symptoms and depression.

Mediation analyses: 
The study will use mediation analysis to investigate if worry, mindfulness (acceptance or awareness) and self-referential processing mediate depression, somatic symptoms and stress in participants with SPS. The study will control for neuroticism and introversion. 

Binary logistic regression: 
- The study will run binary logistic regressions to test the likelihood of having allergies/intolerances with sensory processing sensitivity. 
- The study will also run binary logistic regression to test the likelihood of having more severe depression with sensory processing sensitivity.

q21.value: The study will use the standard a = .05 and two-tailed test. The study will also use the false discovery rate to control for false positives.

q22.value:
If participants are under the age of 18 years old, they will be excluded from the data. The participants will complete 4 attention manipulations and if the participants answer incorrectly on any one of these their data will be excluded. 

If participants are answering on a phone or iPad/tablet the participants will be excluded from the SRET variables. Extreme outliers will also be excluded from the sub-questionnaire based on Durbin-Watson and Cook's distance.

q23.value:
Participants are not able to skip any questions on the questionnaires. 

Participants who complete the survey on a phone/iPad/tablet will be excluded from the SRET data, but their data will be used in other analyses. 

Participants who answer faster than 200ms in a trial will be excluded from that trial. Participants who are too slow on a trial in the SRET will also have the data excluded from that trial. If participants are too slow will be based on the absolute deviation around the median which will be used to identify and exclude outliers on each DV. However, if the participants have less than 50% of data available from the 40 trials, they will be excluded from the SRET data.

q24.value:
The study may explore how many of the current participants completed the survey by Sorensen (2019). 
The study may also calculate how long the participants took to complete the survey.

q25.value:
The current study is replicating the author's undergraduate dissertation but has changed the depression scale from the Personal Health Questionnaire (PHQ-8) to the World Health Organisation depression scale (MDI), removed scales assessing rumination and reflection and also added self-referential processing. 

The current study will collect data from similar websites as the undergraduate dissertation which means there may be overlapping in participants which will be checked by asking the participants if they took part in the previous study.

attributes.title: PSY305: APA Writing Project Assignment
attributes.description: APA Writing Project for PSY305 Winter 2020
attributes.withdrawal_justification: I accidentally published this pre-reg. for a class assignment. It was not meant to be public. The original authors are Madeline Springle, Laura Tian, and Emily Schwartzman.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

attributes.title: Open Scientific Practices in Journalism Studies

q1.value: Prevalence of Open, Good, and Questionable Research Practices in Quantitative Journalism Studies

q3.value: Open Scientific Practices, such as preregistrations and open data and analysis code are being increasingly adopted by social scientists. In this study, we investigate in how far such practices have been adopted by Journalism Studies, a sub-field of Communication Studies. Further, we investigate in how far questionable research practices are common in published papers within the discipline.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will conduct a content analysis of quantitative studies published in "Journalism", "Journalism & Mass Communication Quarterly", "Journalism Studies", "Digital Journalism", and "Journalism Practice" between 2010 and 2019.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The Journals will be accessed online. The Abstracts and Keywords of all Papers published in Issues within our time-frame of interest will be scanned to determine if they employed quantitative methods. If this information is not clear based on the abstract, the methods section will be scanned. Papers that solely report results from secondary data are not included. 

The papers in the sample will then be coded according to our codebook.

q13.value: Sample size is not determined a priori. All papers reporting original quantitative published 2015-19 in the five Journals mentioned above will be analyzed, if they are clearly concerned with journalism studies (i.e. papers from JMCQ that investigate other aspects of mass comm are not included).

q14.value: The awareness for open and good scientific practices his a relatively new phenomenon, hence we only collect data from 2015 onward.

question.value: Not applicable.

All measured variables are explained in the registered codebook. Note that this is the first version, which has not undergone a pretest and reliability tests. After those have been conducted, refinement on some categories may be necessary. The codebook will be updated accordingly and the new version will be uploaded. For transparency, we will not delete the current version.
Not applicable.
No hypothesis tests will be performed.

q20.value:
Some categories that are currently not dichotomous will be recoded to binary variables for exploratory analyses (see below). Specifically this will be done for the following categories: 
PREREG, INSTR, DATA, CODE, PER_VAR

q22.value: If a category from our codebook fails to reach sufficient reliability after three rounds of refinement, it will be dropped.

q24.value: We will employ crosstables with Chi² significance tests to explore differences between journals.

attributes.title: EARLY ADVERSITY AND WOMEN’S SEXUAL BEHAVIOR:  THE ROLE OF NEUROBIOLOGICAL SENSITIVITY TO SEXUAL REWARD

summary.value:
Early adversity and women’s sexual behavior: The role of neurobiological sensitivity to sexual reward. 
     In the United States about one-eighth of individuals in the are exposed to adversity such as sexual abuse, physical abuse, and or neglect prior to the age of 18 (Banducci, Hoffman, Lejuez & Koenen, 2014). Individuals exposed to early adversity are more likely to engage in sexual behaviors that place them at risk for sexual health problems such as engaging sex at earlier ages, unprotected sex, and higher numbers of sexual partners (e.g., Hillis, Anda, Felitti & Marchbanks, 2001; Senn & Carey, 2010). Life history theory offers insight into this relationship, however, researcher have yet to apply LHT to the undertheorized link between early adversity and same-sex behavior. Compared to heterosexuals, sexual-minority minority individuals are disproportionately likely to report childhood experiences of adversity (e.g., Hughes et al., 2014; McLaughlin, Hatzenbuehler, Xuan & Conron, 2012) as well as increased engagement in risky behaviors such as early sexual initiation, higher numbers of sexual partners and higher rates of general sexual risk-taking (e.g., Kerr, Ding, & Thompson, 2013; Tornello, Riskind & Patterson, 2014). 
     While there have been many mediating mechanisms offered in existing research, they have yet to fully address the wide range of sexual risks seen in women who experience early adversity. Behavioral and self-report data suggest that individuals exposed to early adversity exhibit greater impulsiveness and sensation seeking which are reward-motivated behaviors (e.g., Ansell, Gu, Tuit & Sinha, 2012; Katz, Fromme & D’amico, 2000). Neurobiological research suggests brain activation changes in response to rewards in those who experience early adversity however the results are extremely varied (Novick et al., 2018). Considering the mixed results coupled with unique aspects of female sexual risk-taking and female same-sex behavior, I propose that heightened neurobiological sensitivity to sexual rewards may be one of the mechanisms linking early adversity to later sexual risk behavior including but not limited to same-sex behavior, and my research seeks to test this possibility in a sample of women with diverse sexual orientations.
Current Study. 
     By way of this project, I aim to examine further the association between early adversity and later sexual risk-taking including same-sex behavior. I hypothesize that a key mediating mechanism may be a heightened sensitivity to sexual rewards. I will use both self-report methods and an experimental EEG task to test for individual differences in neurobiological sensitivity to sexual rewards in a sample of women with a broad range of exposure to early adversity. 
Hypotheses (confirmatory) 
1.	Individuals with higher exposure to adversity (e.g., greater ACES scores, greater perceived unpredictability, lower childhood SES) will show greater neurobiological sensitivity to sexual rewards (EEG;  greater mean amplitude in the RewP in the modified doors task).
2.	Heightened sexual reward sensitivity (EEG; RewP) should also be associated with self-reported impulsiveness and high-risk sexual behavior including but not limited to same-sex activity (e.g., higher sexual partner number male and female, younger sexual initiation age, higher number of one night stands male and female, lower safe sex behavior scores, more unrestricted SOI). 
3.	Sexual reward sensitivity (EEG, RewP) will mediate the links between early adversity and later sexual risk behavior including but not limited to same-sex activity. 
Hypotheses (exploratory) 
1.	In order to accurately assess the experimental EEG task, I plan to examine not only the component titled RewP but other components validated in previous research such as the P300 component. 
2.	I also plan to examine RewP and reward sensitivity more broadly using a previously validated EEG task called the doors task. 
3.	I also plan to examine potential self-report measures of reward sensitivity, such as impulsiveness, sensation seeking and perceptions of rewards vs. punishments across various activities. I plan to do to further understand reward sensitivity in this sample. Specifically I would examine if individuals who take higher risks are more sensitive to potential rewards or simply more aversive to potential punishments.   
Methods. 
     The proposed project consists of two phases of data collection. First being a questionnaire phase. In this questionnaire phase, participants will consist of 192 women of diverse sexual orientations. The second phase will be an EEG assessment in this phase 50-60 women will be randomly selected from the pool of 192 women.
Sample Size Determination: Based on the funding we have available to us we are able to collect 192 women for the self-report portion of the study and up to 60 women for the self-report plus EEG portions of the study. If we are able to procure more funding we will attempt to recruit more women to increase our overall sample size. 
Procedures: 
     All women (n = 192) will report experiences of early adversity (e.g., predicted lifespan, perceived childhood unpredictability, Adverse childhood experiences/ACES, childhood SES), sexual behavior history with both male and female partners (e.g., sexual partner number, sociosexuality, safe sex behavior, sexual initiation age), and self-reported general and sexual reward sensitivity (e.g., behavioral avoidance/Inhibition scale, sensitivity to punishment and reward questionnaire). A random subset of women will partake in the EEG portion of this study. Each woman will be fitted with a 32-electrode site EEG cap. The EEG lab session will consist of two separate tasks, the doors task and a modified doors task, presented in random order. The modified doors task will assess sexual reward sensitivity using sexual stimuli (pictures of partnered and solo sexual activity) and is the primary focus of the current project. 
Designed from procedures outlined in similar studies (van Lankveld & Smulders, 2008; Prause, Steele, Staley & Sabantinelli, 2015). This task will consist of 200 total trials (100 neutral images, 100 sexual images) in 4 blocks (50 trials each block) using sexual images as the stimuli. Each trial will begin with participants choosing between two doors, following their choice they are presented with a fixation cross (500 ms). Following this fixation cross will be presented with one of two images (neutral or sexual) (2000ms). I will create an average ERP waveform for both sexy and neutral conditions independently. After doing that I will subtract the average neutral wave from the average sexy wave to create a difference wave which represents RewP, (a component used to index how sensitive an individual is to rewards) (Holroyd, Krigolson & Lee, 2011; Lukie, Montazer-Hojat & Holroyd, 2014).

attributes.title: Regular polysemy and novel word-sense identification

q1.value: Regular polysemy and novel word-sense identification

q2.value: Alizée Lombard, Lucie Barque, Doriane Gras, Richard Huyghe

q3.value: Little experimental work has been done on how lexical innovations are contextually detected by speakers (Gardin et al. 1974, Sablayrolles 2003, Frisson and Pickering 2007, Rodd et al. 2012). Existing studies highlight differences as to whether lexical innovation applies to form and/or meaning. It has been argued that neological intuition (i.e. the speakers’ ability to evaluate lexical novelty) depends on at least two linguistic variables: the (non-)novelty of the form and the (non-)regularity of the process that produces neologisms. In this study we focus on the latter, and investigate the effect of polysemy regularity (Apresjan 1974) on the identification of novel word senses in French. Novel word senses are created for the experiment, either by metaphor or metonymy, and used alternatively in their original sense or in the new one. Furthermore, we distinguish degrees of polysemy regularity and hypothesize that they determine metalinguistic judgments about lexical novelty. The more regular a novel word sense is, the less neologically salient it is, and the more neological intuition it is likely to raise. We test this hypothesis by presenting target words in simple sentences to French native speakers.

q4.value:
The experiment is designed to test the following hypotheses:
1. The identification of novel senses is more important in the novel sense conditions than in the original sense conditions. This effect is more important for low regularity than for high regularity. 
2. When identified by the participants as novel, low regularity novel word senses cause shorter response times than high regularity novel word senses.
3. Fixation times are longer in the novel sense conditions than in the original sense conditions. In particular, low regularity novel word senses cause longer fixation times than high regularity novel word senses. 
4. Backtrackings are more important in the novel sense conditions than in the original sense conditions (if enough data is collected). This effect is more important for low regularity than for high regularity.
5. Effects listed in 1-4 are more important for metaphorical novel word senses than for metonymic novel word senses.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Two-group within-subject design with 2 principal factors (degree of regularity and polysemy pattern figure) and 2 modalities each (resp. low/high and metaphor/metonymy). The 4 experimental conditions result from the combination of these modalities.
The stimuli are sentences including target words that are either used in their original sense, or in a novel sense especially created for the experiment. These novel senses follow different existing polysemy patterns with different degrees of regularity. Each neological stimulus (i.e. sentence including a word used in a novel sense) is paired with a neutral stimulus (i.e. sentence including the same word used in the original sense). The stimuli will be counterbalanced between the two groups of participants in such a way that each participant will see half of the neutral stimuli and the other half of the neological stimuli. Neological stimuli will equally frequently appear with the novel and the original sense in the overall experiment. Sentences will be presented in a random order.
The experiment has 2 phases. In Phase 1, participants are asked to indicate whether or not there is a word used in a novel sense in a series of 100 sentences. In Phase 2, they are asked to precisely identify the word with a novel sense in each sentence that resulted in a positive response in Phase 1.

q9.value: We will use simple randomization, where the participants of each group will see the same stimuli in a different order. The randomization is generated by an option included in the software used to design the experiment (https://www.sr-research.com/experiment-builder/).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The experiment will be advertised on a diffusion list for experiments in cognitive science, as well as on the information boards of the university where it takes place. People interested in participating to the experiment will receive the information leaflet by email when contacting us. Participants will be volunteers. They must be French native speakers, be between 18 and 30 years old, have a normal or corrected vision (except for progressive or bifocal lenses), not having undergone laser corrective surgery and not suffer from any of the following conditions: macular degeneration, glaucoma, cataract, strabismus, nystagmus.
Prior to the experiment, participants will answer a questionnaire to verify that they meet the conditions for participating. The complete experiment, including greeting, briefing, signing of consent and data acquisition, should take approximately 45 minutes.
The stimuli will be presented to participants on a computer screen using SR Research Experiment Builder software. The whole sentence will appear on the computer screen until the trigger of an answer key.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 40 participants. We will attempt to recruit as many participants as possible in order to have the most accurate results.

q14.value: Registering participants is limited to 3 weeks.

question.value:
We manipulate six independent variables.
Variable 1 is the lexical figure characterizing the polysemy relation involved in novel sense creation. It is a categorical variable with two modalities: metaphor and metonymy.
Variable 2 is the degree of regularity of the polysemy relation involved in novel sense creation. It is a categorical variable with two modalities: high and low regularity. 
Variable 3 is the target word sense. It is a categorical variable with two modalities: original and novel.
Variable 4 is the frequency of the target word. It is a continuous variable.
Variable 5 is the length of the target word (measured in characters). It is a continuous variable.
Variable 6 is the length of the stimulus sentence (measured in characters). It is a continuous variable.

Three types of variables will be measured during the experiment.
1. We will observe whether target words with novel senses are identified or not. We will measure this categorical variable by asking participants (i) if there is a word used in a novel sense in a given stimulus sentence, and (ii) where relevant, what this word is.
2. We will observe response time. We will measure this continuous variable by measuring the time between the appearance of the stimulus on the display PC screen and the pressing of the reply button.
3. We will observe the participants’ eye movements, eye-tracked with a noninvasive tracking device (Eyelink Portable Duo), with a focus on target word fixation time and backtracking.
Each measured variable will be analyzed separately since they may correlate with different metalinguistic or cognitive phenomena.

We will perform the analyses using mixed-effects models with crossed random effects for subjects and items on R (R Core Team 2015) with the lme4 package (Bates et al. 2014). Statistical significance will be assessed based on a log-likelihood ratio test between models with and without the relevant variables.
1. Identification will be analyzed using a logistic mixed-effects regression with target word frequency, the interaction of regularity degree factor and target word sense variable, the interaction of figure factor and target word sense variable, as simple effects with random intercepts on participants and stimuli and random slopes on participants. The effect of regularity degree on the novel sense conditions will be analyzed through Tukey post-hoc tests.
2. Response time will be analyzed using a linear mixed-effects regression with target word frequency, regularity degree factor and figure factor, as simple effects with random intercepts on participants and on stimuli, and random slopes on participants. 
3. Fixation time will be analyzed using a linear mixed-effects regression with target word frequency, the interaction of regularity degree factor and target word sense variable, the interaction of figure factor and target word sense variable, as simple effects with random intercepts on participants and stimuli, and random slopes on participants. The effect of regularity degree on the novel sense conditions will be analyzed through Tukey post-hoc tests.
4. Backtracking data, if consistent enough, will be analyzed using a logistic mixed-effects regression with target word frequency, the interaction of regularity degree factor and target word sense variable, the interaction of figure factor and target word sense variable, as simple effects with random intercepts on participants and stimuli, and random slopes on participants. The effect of regularity degree on the novel sense conditions will be analyzed through Tukey post-hoc tests.

q20.value:
Each categorical variable in the mixed-effects models will be dummy coded. The reference category will be high for the regularity degree, metaphor for the figure and novel for the word sense.
Concerning the measured variable for the identification, the response registered as “identified” will be stimuli in which participants indicated the existence of a word used in a novel sense at the first task and with the word successfully identified at the second task.
The measured variables of response times and fixation times will be transformed in order to simplify the analysis models. We will divide response times by the sentence length and fixation times by the tested word length.

q21.value: The level of significance will be set at 5% (p<.05) for both mixed-effects models and post-hoc tests.

q22.value:
All data from a given participant will be eliminated if positive answer rate on neutral stimuli is greater than 2.5 SD above the average rate.
Answers shorter than 1000ms will be eliminated from the analysis data, basing on the fact that below this threshold participants are not able to accurately read stimuli sentences and make an informed metalinguistic judgment.
Response time and fixation time data will be trimmed by 2.5 SD around by-participant and by-condition means, to ensure that the observed effects are not only due to extreme values.
The best model eventually chosen will be run without the residuals whose absolute value is greater than 2.5 SD, to ensure that the effects are not only due to outliers.

q23.value: When the eye tracker is unable to capture enough eye movement, the data will not be representative of the participants' behaviour. If there is more than 25% trackloss for a given trial, this trial will not be taken into account in the statistical analyses.

q24.value: We expect that word frequency may be related to neological identification. Therefore, we will look for relationships between word frequency and the primary outcome of identification measures.

q25.value:
Apresjan, J. (1974). Regular Polysemy. In : Linguistics (42): 5-32.
Bates, D., Maechler, M., Bolker, B. and Walker, S. (2014). lme4: Linear mixed-effects models using Eigen and S4. R package
version 1.1–6. Url: http://CRAN.R-project.org/package=lme4
Ben Hariz Ouenniche, S. (2009). Diminuer les fluctuations du sentiment néologique. In: Neologica (3) : 37–51.
Frisson, S. and Pickering, M. (2007).  The processing of familiar and novel senses of a word: Why reading Dickens is easy but reading Needham can be hard. Language and Cognitive Processes, 22(4), 595–613.
Gardin, B., Lefèvre, G., Marcellesi, C., and Mortureux, M.-F. (1974). A propos du « sentiment néologique ». In: Langages (36): 45-52.
R Core Team. (2015). R: A language and environment for statistical computing. Vienna: R Foundation for Statistical Computing. Url: http://www.R-project.org/
Rodd, J. M., Berriman, R., Landau, M., Lee, T., Ho, C., Gaskell, M. G., and Davis, M. H. (2012).  Learning new meanings for old words:  Effects of semantic relatedness. Memory and Cognition, 40(7), 1095-1108.
Sablayrolles, J.-F. (2003). Le Sentiment néologique. In: L’Innovation lexicale. Dir. J.-F. Sablayrolles. Paris, Champion: 279–295.

registration_responses.q19.question:
We will perform the analyses using mixed-effects models with crossed random effects for subjects and items on R (R Core Team 2015) with the lme4 package (Bates et al. 2014). Statistical significance will be assessed based on a log-likelihood ratio test between models with and without the relevant variables.
1. Identification will be analyzed using a logistic mixed-effects regression with target word frequency, the interaction of regularity degree factor and target word sense variable, the interaction of figure factor and target word sense variable, as simple effects with random intercepts on participants and stimuli and random slopes on participants. The effect of regularity degree on the novel sense conditions will be analyzed through Tukey post-hoc tests.
2. Response time will be analyzed using a linear mixed-effects regression with target word frequency, regularity degree factor and figure factor, as simple effects with random intercepts on participants and on stimuli, and random slopes on participants. 
3. Fixation time will be analyzed using a linear mixed-effects regression with target word frequency, the interaction of regularity degree factor and target word sense variable, the interaction of figure factor and target word sense variable, as simple effects with random intercepts on participants and stimuli, and random slopes on participants. The effect of regularity degree on the novel sense conditions will be analyzed through Tukey post-hoc tests.
4. Backtracking data, if consistent enough, will be analyzed using a logistic mixed-effects regression with target word frequency, the interaction of regularity degree factor and target word sense variable, the interaction of figure factor and target word sense variable, as simple effects with random intercepts on participants and stimuli, and random slopes on participants. The effect of regularity degree on the novel sense conditions will be analyzed through Tukey post-hoc tests.

attributes.title: Estimating the reproducibility & transparency of smoking cessation behaviour change interventions

q1.value: Estimating the reproducibility and transparency of smoking cessation behaviour change interventions (2018-2019)

q2.value: Emma Norris, Robert West, Susan Michie

q3.value:
The fields of psychology and health research are becoming increasingly aware of the importance of research behaviours that promote replication and transparency (Nosek et al., 2015; Munafo et al., 2017). Reproducibility-related behaviours include pre-registering studies and publishing protocols, Open Access publishing and sharing data, study materials and analysis. Transparency-related behaviours include reporting funding sources and conflicts of interest. These research behaviours are especially crucial in the area of smoking cessation, where tobacco and pharmaceutical companies may have vested interests in the findings of health promotion research (Garne et al. 2005). This study applies a methodology previously used to assess reproducibility in the psychological sciences (Hardwicke et al. 2020).

The aim of this study is to assess the transparency and reproducibility of smoking cessation behaviour change interventions. 
The research questions for this study are: 
i) What is the estimated reproducibility of smoking cessation behaviour change interventions?
ii) What is the estimated transparency of smoking cessation behaviour change interventions?

q4.value: We do not have any a priori hypotheses.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Retrospective observational study

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Identification of smoking cessation behaviour change papers: We identified 100 randomised controlled trial behaviour change intervention papers published 2018-2019 from the Cochrane Tobacco Group Specialised Register of controlled trials (https://tobacco.cochrane.org/resources/cochrane-tag-specialised-register). The Register was searched in November 2019, identifying 1630 papers from 2018 & 2019. Inclusion criteria were that the studies must be Randomised Controlled Trials: required for the parallel Human Behaviour-Change Project (Michie et al., 2017; https://osf.io/efp4x/). Exclusion criteria included trial protocols, abstract-only entries and economic or process evaluations. 157 papers remained after applying these criteria, with 100 papers randomly selected from these. PDFs of these 100 papers were obtained from journal websites.

Extraction of data on transparency and reproducibility: Data will be extracted onto a Google Form (https://tinyurl.com/skxfxc3) (see Measured variables for details on what was extracted). All papers will be independently coded by two researchers. Any discrepancies will be resolved through discussion, with input from a third researcher if required.

q14.value: 100 papers are being analysed due to time restraints and personnel capacity. All papers will be double-coded.

question.value:
Measured variables and their operationalizations are shown in Table 1. Identified measured variables have been adapted from a previous study assessing the transparency and reproducibility in psychological sciences (Hardwicke et al. 2020).

Data will be extracted onto a Google Form (https://tinyurl.com/skxfxc3). All papers will be independently coded by two researchers. Any discrepancies will be resolved through discussion, with input from a third researcher if required.

For each measured variable, we will report raw numbers and percentages. Reproducibility will be assessed using the descriptive statistics of pre-registration, protocol-, data-, materials- and analysis script-sharing, attempts at replication and open access publishing questions. Transparency of identified studies will be assessed using the descriptive statistics of funding and conflicts of interest questions.

Inter-rater reliability of the two researchers’ coding will be calculated using Krippendorff’s alpha.

attributes.title: Supplemental materials for preprint: UPAYA MENGURANGI MISKONSEPSI PADA PEMBELAJARAN FISIKA MELALUI PENERAPAN MODEL CREATIVE PROBLEM SOLVING
attributes.description: The purpose of this paper is to describe efforts to reduce misconceptions in learning physics through the application of creative problem solving models. This writing is motivated by the large number of students who still experience misconceptions in learning physics. For this reason, efforts need to be made to reduce misconceptions in learning physics by applying the creative problem solving model. The method used in this paper is the study of literature by studying some literature to be analyzed and made conclusions. The results of this paper indicate that the application of this creative problem solving model can be a solution in an effort to reduce misconceptions in learning physics. Because, creative problem solving models can improve students' understanding of concepts and skills, so students will better understand the concept by searching for themselves and solving problems independently but still not free from teacher guidance. Teachers can also actively involve students in the physics learning process.
tags: Miskonsepsi, Creative Problem Solving, Pembelajaran Fisika

q1.value: UPAYA MENGURANGI MISKONSEPSI PADA PEMBELAJARAN FISIKA MELALUI PENERAPAN MODEL CREATIVE PROBLEM SOLVING

q3.value: Tujuan penulisan ini untuk mendeskripsikan upaya mengurangi miskonsepsi pada materi dinamika rotasi melalui penerapan model creative problem solving. Penulisan ini dilatarbelakangi oleh banyaknya peserta didik yang masih terjadi miskonsepsi pada pembelajaran fisika. Untuk itu perlu ada upaya untuk mengurangi miskonsepsi pada pembelajaran fisika yaitu dengan penerapan model creative problem solving. Metode yang digunakan dalam penulisan ini adalah studi kepustakaan dengan mengkaji beberapa literatur untuk dianalisis dan dibuat kesimpulan. Hasil penulisan ini menunjukkan bahwa penerapan model creative problem solving ini dapat menjadi solusi dalam upaya untuk mengurangi miskonsepsi pada pembelajaran fisika. Karena, model creative problem solving dapat meningkatkan pemahaman konsep dan keterampilan peserta didik, sehingga peserta didik akan lebih memahami konsep dengan cara mencari sendiri dan memecahkan masalahnya secara mandiri namun tetap tidak lepas dari bimbingan pengajar. Pengajar juga dapat melibatkan peserta didik secara aktif dalam proses pembelajaran fisika.

question.value: Model creative Problem solving selain dapat meningkatkan kemampuan peserta didik untuk berfikir kreatif juga dapat meningkatkan kemampuan peserta didik dalam menyelesaikan masalah, serta dapat meningkatkan kemampuan komunikasi peserta didik seperti contohnya dengan melakukan presentasi. Pada model creative problem solving digunakan pemusatan pada pengajaran dan keterampilan pemecahan masalah, yang diikuti dengan penguatan keterampilan. Ketika peserta didik dihadapkan pada suatu permasalahan seperti adanya miskonsepsi materi fisika maka peserta didik dapat melakukan keterampilan memecahkan masalah untuk memilih dan mengembangkan ide serta pemikirannya. Namun, tidak terlepas juga dari komunikasi dengan pengajar untuk mengurangi adanya kesalahan konsep seperti misalnya antara konsep yang memang sudah ada dengan konsep yang dialami peserta didik di kehidupan sehari-hari.

Berdasarkan hasil studi kepustakaan, bahwa model creative problem solving dapat menjadi salah satu upaya untuk mengurangi miskonsepsi pembelajaran fisika. Model creative problem solving dapat meningkatkan pemahaman konsep dan keterampilan peserta didik. Penerapan
model creative problem solving dalam upaya mengurangi miskonsepsi ini telah memenuhi indikator keberhasilan, dimana model creative problem solving dapat meningkatkan aktivitas belajar peserta didik. Sehingga, dengan meningkatnya keterampilan peserta didik maka akan menambah semangat untuk mempelajari konsep yang telah ada dan terjamin keabsahannya khususnya konsep pada pembelajaran fisika dan pengajar dapat mengikutseratakan peserta didik secara aktif dalam proses pembelajaran.

attributes.title: depressed mood and behavioral risk taking

q1.value: Does depressed mood predict less risk taking in the Balloon Analogue Risk Task

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to examine the relationship between depressed mood and decisions in the Balloon Analogue Risk Task (BART).

q4.value: The primary prediction is that depressed mood (as measured by 7 items from the CES-D) is negatively correlated with the most common measure of risk taking from the BART, corrected mean number of pumps (does not included trials in which a balloon popped). We also predict that depressed mood will be negatively correlated with uncorrected mean number of pumps, earnings in the BART, and number of balloons popped.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a correlational study. All participants complete the BART and a measure of depressed mood.

q9.value: The order of the 40 trials of the BART are randomized individually for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will collect data from participants who are college students. They will receive credit toward the completion of a research requirement.

q13.value: We will collect data until we have data from at least 193 participants.

q14.value: We set the smallest meaningful relationship between depressed mood and risky decisions at r = .20. Using G*Power with the assumptions of two tailed alpha = .05, we determined that we need 193 participants to have a power of .80.

q15.value: Because we need to schedule participants in batches and we don't know how many people will sign up and complete the study, we will schedule participants for full weeks of research assistant time until we finish a week that includes the 193rd participant. We will likely end up with more than 193 participants.

question.value: Nothing is manipulated. The balloons pop at various sizes, but this is not going to be examined.

We will measure several variables. We will measure participants' depressed mood using 7 items from the CES-D. We will also gather demographics (age, gender, political affiliation). The BART will give us several outcomes: corrected number of pumps, uncorrected number of pumps, number of balloons popped, and earnings.

We will take the average response to the 7 CESD items as a measure of depressed mood. For the BART, we will calculated corrected mean pumps by removing trials in which balloons popped. Uncorrected mean pumps will include all trials.
We will run a set of bivariate correlations with depressed affect and 1) mean corrected pumps, 2) mean uncorrected pumps, 3) earnings, and 4) balloons popped.

q24.value: We will also explore the relationship between political ideology and performance on the BART.

attributes.title: Effect of dietary-based weight loss preoperatively on postoperative outcomes in obesity: study protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Effect of dietary-based weight loss preoperatively on postoperative outcomes in obesity: study protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis

q3.value: More obese patients are undergoing surgery due to the rising incidence of obesity in the community. Obese patients are more likely to experience postoperative complications, resulting in greater health and financial burdens. Consequently, obese patients are often advised to lose weight before surgery to reduce pain, improve health outcomes and lower the risk of postoperative complications. However, little evidence exists to confirm whether preoperative diet-based weight loss interventions decrease adverse events following surgery in obese populations. Thus, the purpose of this systematic review is to evaluate the effect of dietary-based weight loss preoperatively on postoperative outcomes in the obese population.

q4.value: The hypothesis is that diet-based weight loss prior to surgery reduces postoperative complications and improves outcomes in obese patients undergoing specific elective surgeries.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Please see systematic review protocol attached.

Participants/Population
Adults aged 18 years or older classified as obese, with a Body Mass Index (BMI) greater than or equal to 30 kg/m2, who were awaiting elective surgery. Surgeries will include, but not be limited to, orthopaedic procedures, cardiac surgery, and gastrointestinal surgeries. Participants with a history of cancer or those undergoing bariatric surgery will be excluded. 

Intervention
The review will focus on studies that implement a diet-based weight loss intervention prior to surgery. The specific type of intervention undertaken will be recorded and classified according to these groups: dietary modification (including factors such as protein, carbohydrates and fat specific goals), caloric restriction, meal replacement, etc. Studies will be excluded that include pharmacological weight loss, exercise alone or bariatric surgery as the weight loss intervention prior to elective surgery, or weight loss prior to bariatric surgery.

Comparator
This review will consider studies that compared the intervention to a control group that did not undergo specific preoperative weight loss intervention. The control will be usual or standard care for patients on a waiting list for an elective surgery that can consist of, but not be limited to advice about healthy eating provided by a preadmission clinic or GP.

Types of studies to be included:
Prospective studies including randomised controlled trials and non-randomised controlled trials, and cohort studies will be included. Retrospective studies (including studies retrospectively assessing registry data) will be excluded.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
The following electronic databases will be searched from inception to the current date:
- MEDLINE
- EMBASE
- Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (eligible reviews will have their references reviewed and include eligible studies in this review)
- Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL)
- CINAHL
- Scopus
- ClinicalTrials.gov
- WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (WHO ICTRP)

There will be no limitation on the year of publication. Reference lists of included studies, as well as grey literature, will also be reviewed for additional studies. 

Standardised forms will be used by two independent reviewers to extract and collate data from eligible studies. Disagreement will be resolved through discussion. Corresponding authors will be contacted if there is key information missing from their studies. The following data items will be extracted:
- Title
- Author
- Year of publication
- Journal
- Study design
- Setting
- Participant characteristics (e.g. age, gender, diagnosis, BMI, etc)
- Recruitment procedures utilised
- Trial size (at baseline and during analysis for intervention and control groups)
- Preoperative weight loss intervention characteristics (e.g. type of intervention such as dietary modification, caloric restriction, meal replacement diets, etc, the duration of the intervention, whether a dietitian administered the intervention, the quality, etc)
- Details of the control/comparator if there is one
- Type of surgery
- Follow up or study duration
- Outcomes
- Outcome measurements
- Data analysis methods
- Details needed for assessment for risk of bias
- Author contact details
- Funding source

The primary outcome will be postoperative complications to 90 days that will include venous thromboembolism (VTE), superficial site infections, deep wound infections, other infections not related to the wound (e.g. urinary tract infection and chest infection), wound disturbances (dehiscence, significant ooze defined as need to apply a vacuum dressing or need to withhold anticoagulants), cerebrovascular accidents (CVA), myocardial infarction, peri or postoperative fracture, dislocation, revision surgery, readmission and death. 

Secondary outcomes will include amount of weight loss (measured in kilograms or the proportion of participants losing 5% or more prior to surgery), acute length of hospital stay measured in days, discharge destination (including home and inpatient rehabilitation), duration of inpatient rehabilitation, patient-reported outcomes for pain, function and quality of life (measured with validated scales such as, VAS, NPRS, EQ5D, SF-36, etc) collected immediately postoperatively, at one month, three months and one year follow up, time taken to return to work in any capacity, and time taken to return to full work duties.

Data analysis will be performed according to intention to treat. The treatment effect for each trial will be measured according to the outcome. The difference between dichotomous outcomes will be presented as risk ratios (RRs), while results from continuous outcomes will be reported as either the mean difference (MD), if the same measurement tool was used, or standardised mean difference (SMD), if the outcome was measured with different tools. The 95% confidence intervals (CIs) will be calculated for both dichotomous and continuous outcomes.

If appropriate, random-effects meta-analysis will be performed to pool outcomes from studies with similar characteristics (such as participants, interventions, outcome measures, and timing of outcome measurement). At least two studies will be required for this. In cases of heterogeneity where the I² statistic is 60% or greater, a sensitivity analysis will be performed, excluding trials with a high risk of bias. Subgroup analyses will be performed on surgery and diet type, dependent on the number of studies retrieved and their sample size. Another subgroup analysis will be performed on participants who lost weight preoperatively compared to those who did not, regardless of the intervention to which they were allocated to determine the association between weight loss in general and postoperative complications. The completion of this analysis will be dependent on whether the included studies have presented adequate data.

If data cannot be pooled, treatment effect estimates and 95% CIs of each trial will be presented in a table with results summarised in the text.

registration_responses.q1: Effect of dietary-based weight loss preoperatively on postoperative outcomes in obesity: study protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis
registration_responses.q3: More obese patients are undergoing surgery due to the rising incidence of obesity in the community. Obese patients are more likely to experience postoperative complications, resulting in greater health and financial burdens. Consequently, obese patients are often advised to lose weight before surgery to reduce pain, improve health outcomes and lower the risk of postoperative complications. However, little evidence exists to confirm whether preoperative diet-based weight loss interventions decrease adverse events following surgery in obese populations. Thus, the purpose of this systematic review is to evaluate the effect of dietary-based weight loss preoperatively on postoperative outcomes in the obese population.
registration_responses.q4: The hypothesis is that diet-based weight loss prior to surgery reduces postoperative complications and improves outcomes in obese patients undergoing specific elective surgeries.
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q8.question:
Please see systematic review protocol attached.

Participants/Population
Adults aged 18 years or older classified as obese, with a Body Mass Index (BMI) greater than or equal to 30 kg/m2, who were awaiting elective surgery. Surgeries will include, but not be limited to, orthopaedic procedures, cardiac surgery, and gastrointestinal surgeries. Participants with a history of cancer or those undergoing bariatric surgery will be excluded. 

Intervention
The review will focus on studies that implement a diet-based weight loss intervention prior to surgery. The specific type of intervention undertaken will be recorded and classified according to these groups: dietary modification (including factors such as protein, carbohydrates and fat specific goals), caloric restriction, meal replacement, etc. Studies will be excluded that include pharmacological weight loss, exercise alone or bariatric surgery as the weight loss intervention prior to elective surgery, or weight loss prior to bariatric surgery.

Comparator
This review will consider studies that compared the intervention to a control group that did not undergo specific preoperative weight loss intervention. The control will be usual or standard care for patients on a waiting list for an elective surgery that can consist of, but not be limited to advice about healthy eating provided by a preadmission clinic or GP.

Types of studies to be included:
Prospective studies including randomised controlled trials and non-randomised controlled trials, and cohort studies will be included. Retrospective studies (including studies retrospectively assessing registry data) will be excluded.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The following electronic databases will be searched from inception to the current date:
- MEDLINE
- EMBASE
- Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (eligible reviews will have their references reviewed and include eligible studies in this review)
- Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL)
- CINAHL
- Scopus
- ClinicalTrials.gov
- WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (WHO ICTRP)

There will be no limitation on the year of publication. Reference lists of included studies, as well as grey literature, will also be reviewed for additional studies. 

Standardised forms will be used by two independent reviewers to extract and collate data from eligible studies. Disagreement will be resolved through discussion. Corresponding authors will be contacted if there is key information missing from their studies. The following data items will be extracted:
- Title
- Author
- Year of publication
- Journal
- Study design
- Setting
- Participant characteristics (e.g. age, gender, diagnosis, BMI, etc)
- Recruitment procedures utilised
- Trial size (at baseline and during analysis for intervention and control groups)
- Preoperative weight loss intervention characteristics (e.g. type of intervention such as dietary modification, caloric restriction, meal replacement diets, etc, the duration of the intervention, whether a dietitian administered the intervention, the quality, etc)
- Details of the control/comparator if there is one
- Type of surgery
- Follow up or study duration
- Outcomes
- Outcome measurements
- Data analysis methods
- Details needed for assessment for risk of bias
- Author contact details
- Funding source

attributes.title: Study 4a
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

dataCollectionDates.value: End of February - end of April.

question2a.value: We will use a 2-social comparison (upward standard vs. downward standard) between-participants design.

question2b.value: DV : subjective self-evaluation. To measure the participants’ subjective self-evaluation, we will rely on 1 item ("Right now, you think you are" on a scale from 1 = Not at all attractive to 7 = extremely attractive.)

question3b.value: IV :  Joy.  To measure the participants joy, we will rely on a subscale of the dispositional positive emotion scales (Shiota, Keltner and John, 2006). More precisely, we tried to adapt this dispositional scale to a state scale.

question10b.value:
After validating, participants will have to fill out demographic information (sex, date of birth and study sector).
Next, we will measure participants joy with an adaptation of Shiota, Keltner and John (2006) subscale. 
Thereafter, we will present the social comparison induction as an "attention task". More precisely, participants will be exposed to Léo or Léa profil for 30 seconds. Participants will have to memorize the profil because they will have to recall some of this informations later. 
We will manipulate the standard attractivity by the associated photo profil. More precisely, participants may be exposed to the picture of a moderate attractive young woman/man or to the picture of a moderate unattractive young woman/man. This four pictures were pretested and were extracted from the Chicago face database (Ma, Correll and Wittenbrink, 2015). Furthermore, participants will share the same date of birth than Léa/Léo. After the 30 seconds, we will explain that they will participate to a pretest to leave a little time between the memorization phase and the recall phase. We will aks participants three questions : to what extent they consider themselves to be attractive, nice and intelligent. For these 3 items, participants will have to position themselves on 7-point scales (1=Not at all ; 7= extremely). Then we will ask participants to recall Léa/Léo date of birth, their eye colors, what they like and what are their parents' names. 
Finally, we will ask to participants what they believe to be the purpose of the study. Participants will be thanks and debrief. We will use the software "Qualtrics" to do run this study. We will do this study online and participants will be recruited on a voluntary basis via social networks and mails.

question4b.value: Only participants who are less than thirty years old, who are students, who identify as a woman or a man and who will achieve the study on a computer will be included in the study.

question5b.value: All the data will be collected online via the Qualtrics platform. Participants will be recruited on a voluntary basis via social networks and mails.

question6b.value: In a previous study with a similar design (see preregistration here : https://osf.io/a645y), we observed an effect size of η2 = 0.032. Based on this effect size of η2 = 0.032, a power analysis indicated that for an alpha of .05 and a desired statistical power of 0.90, a total of 320 participants is needed.

question7b.value: We will stop data collection at 400 participants. This will allow us to not drop statistical power after participants exclusion, due to inclusion criteria.

question8b.value:
a) We will exclude participants if they guess our hypothesis.
b) We will exclude participants who fail  the attention checks of social comparison induction. More precisely, we will ask four questions about the comparison standard (e.g : "what are Léa parents' names?"). Participants who make one error will be excluded. 
c) We will exclude participants if they do not speak French fluently (assessed via self-report). 
d) In the analyses,participants outliers will be detected by using outlierTest function on R. Participants associated with studentized residuals with Bonferroni p value inferior of 0.05 will be excluded of the analysis. Also, participants outliers on Cook-D and Leverage (Judd and McClelland, 2011) will be excluded of the analysis. 
e) We will exclude participants if they spent too much time to complete the experiment (more than 15min)

question1a.value:
Few studies have investigated the potential impact of mood on social comparison processes.  In this research project, we expect mood to moderate social comparison effect on self-evaluation. We are especially interested in the impact of positive mood (specifically joy) on social comparison processes. In three studies, we found preliminary evidence that joy can shape social comparison processes. (for one of this studies, see preregistration here : https://osf.io/a645y). 
In this current experiment we aim to replicate these results in a correlational design.

question2a.value: Based on our previous studies, we expect to find a contrast effect on neutral mood (Gerber, Wheeler and Suls, 2018). Among the most joyful participants, we expect that this contrast effects to decrease.

question3a.value: No manipulation check will be included because we already checked the attractivity of our social comparison standards in a pilot study.

question5a.value:
There are at least two reasons why a positive mood could moderate social comparison effects : 

a) Joy induces a global focus (Gasper and Clore, 2002 ; Isbell and Lair, 2013) and global focus leads to assimilation. (Forster, Liberman and Kuschel, 2008, Huntsinger, 2014). Thereby, joy can decrease contrast. 

b) Joyful people can process information in ways that maintain their positive affective state (Aspinwall, 1998; Hirt, Devers and McCrea, 2008; Trope, Igou and Burke, 2006). Joy should trigger self-serving mechanism when processing social comparison information. Joy could hence reduce social comparison effect.

question6a.value: Because we expect to replicate our previous results, we predict that joy will decrease the contrast effect.

question1c.value:
We will average the five items from the adaptation  of  Shiota, Keltner and John (2006) subscale.
We will do a linear regression with the joy score and standard direction (upward vs. downward) on self-evaluation of attractiveness.

question2c.value:
General linear model.
We will code the downward standard condition (-.5), upward standard condition (.5), we will center the joy score and compute the product between these two variables to test the interaction. We expect to find a positive estimate for the interaction.

question3c.value:
IV : Comparison standard (2 conditions :upward standard vs. downward  standard). 
DV : Subjective-self evaluation.
Moderator : joy score.
